messageBody:
Hi Brett,

On 6/8/06, Brett L. Schuchert <schuchert@...> wrote:
>
> As for option 2... We're not following agile practices. We are not pair
> programming. We are not doing TDD (write one test, get it to compile, get it
> to run, write the next test...). We are closer to a Unified Process
> mentality. Use cases not user stories. Design reviews, not pair programming.
> Don't refactor until something is broken versus removing code smell as you
> go along. We do have the develops and BA's working together. We do have
> morning stand up meetings. Some are effective, some are just quick status
> reports (ineffective).


Sounds like a typical "real-world" software project to me, don't feel bad if
the Agile practices don't seem very relevant or even practical to you.
I ranted
about this very topic <http://beust.com/weblog/archives/000392.html> a few
days ago.

I check this in. Then in my workspace, I just change the IGNORE_UNTIL to
> something like "6/15/2005", whatever. One change, all the tests being
> running.


For the record, TestNG <http://testng.org> supports "ignores" with groups.
You would put such methods in a certain group:

@Test(groups = {"functional"})
public void g() { ... }

@Test(groups = {"functional", "ignore"})
public void f() { ... }

and then exclude this group from your run (e.g. "include 'functional',
exclude 'ignore'")

Also, the HTML reports generated by TestNG will give you a list of all the
groups and which methods belong to them, so it's very easy to quickly find
out what test methods are currently being ignored.

As for the concept of a time bomb, it's a perfect scenario for TestNG's use
of BeanShell, which lets you override TestNG's decision mechanism and lets
you write the logic that decides which methods should be included or
excluded (in case groups are not good enough).
